pullRequest.body:
Add definition and example of a coalgebra.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,

nodes.body: A nice second example might be https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3694952/1896; I think that would make clear why I suggest the applied lemmas above.
Another good instance to add would be `Coalgebra R R`, which I think is true with the obvious maps.

> Another good instance to add would be `Coalgebra R R`, which I think is true with the obvious maps.

In case you missed it; I think it would be a good idea to include this in this PR too.

> A nice second example might be https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3694952/1896; I think that would make clear why I suggest the applied lemmas above.

I agree but right now we don't need this so it could wait for another PR.

:v: al-ramsey can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7094513444/job/19309917755)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7094513444/job/19309916874)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7094513444/job/19309916618)

Thanks!

bors d+
This looks like a great start; I'm glad to see this migrate from zulip to a PR!

Thank you for this PR, it's great that coalgebras (and I hope Hopf algebras!) are finally arriving.

I have left some suggestions (mostly nitpicks, but I think worth following).

Note that first PRs are always the hardest, especially if they contain new definitions: you should definitely expect future PRs to be much more fun :-)

I'll look again as soon as you've addressed the open suggestions but please feel free to ping me here or on Zulip if you have questions.
LGTM, thanks for the final iteration!

Thanks!

bors d+

Is this in some reasonable sense "canonical"? If so, it should probably be an `instance`.
```suggestion
instance Finsupp.instCoalgebra (R : Type u) (S : Type v) [CommRing R] : Coalgebra R (S  R) where
```

You should add some lemmas after this `class` that state the applied versions of these conditions; these ones are great to have in the definition, but for downstream users it's helpful to also have the other spelling

Just to check: something like  
```lean
@[simp]
theorem coassoc_apply {R : Type u} {A : Type v} [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup A] [Module R A]
    [C : Coalgebra R A] (a : A) : (TensorProduct.assoc R A A A  TensorProduct.map C. .id  C.) a =
    (TensorProduct.map .id C.  C.) a := by
  exact LinearMap.congr_fun C.coassoc a
```
for each of the conditions in the definition?

Not quite; the same proof, but the statement should be ``-free:
```lean
TensorProduct.assoc R A A A (TensorProduct.map C. .id (C. a)) = TensorProduct.map .id C. (C. a)
```
(note also that if you have `by` followed immediately by `exact`, you can *usually* cancel them out)

Thank you! What's the etiquette on resolving conversations? I think I've added the lemmas correctly in the latest commit, but obviously I might be wrong and have made a mistake. Would I still resolve it and if I was wrong a new conversion would be opened?
I don't know if we have a hard rule here; but I'd usually say it's fine for you to resolve things, especially if you add a comment saying "done" or similar at the same time
`(f) = f  f` looks like it would make a good `lemma`; can you try to prove it?
I might have misunderstood you here (isn't it true almost by definition?) but I've added this in the latest commit.
Things which are true almost by definition are precisely the first lemmas that you should be writing! What you have is exactly what I meant.

This looks like a good use-case for `variable`:
```suggestion
variable {R : Type u} {A : Type v}
variable [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup A] [Module R A] [C : Coalgebra R A]

@[simp]
theorem coassoc_apply (a : A) : TensorProduct.assoc R A A A (TensorProduct.map C. .id (C. a)) =
    TensorProduct.map .id C. (C. a) := LinearMap.congr_fun C.coassoc a

@[simp]
theorem _id_apply (a : A) : TensorProduct.lid R A (TensorProduct.map C. .id (C. a)) = a :=
  LinearMap.congr_fun C._id a

@[simp]
theorem id__apply (a : A) : TensorProduct.rid R A (TensorProduct.map .id C. (C. a)) = a :=
  LinearMap.congr_fun C.id_ a
```
I've changed this, but put it inside a section to keep it separate from the later explicit `R`.

This raises that something a big ugly is going on here; for algebras, we wouldn't usually write `Alg.algebraMap r` (where `Alg : Algebra R A`), we write `algebraMap R A r` instead.

One (ugly) option would be to repeat this pattern, and rename `` to `'` so that you can then `def  := '`, but with an explicit `R` variable.

You might also be able to get away with ` (R := R)` instead of `C.` without changing anything else, which we didn't have as an option when `Algebra` was designed.

I think since I added the `namespace Coalgebra` I can replace `C : Coalgebra R A` with just `Coalgebra R A` and `C.` with just `` and it seems to work fine? But then in general, if I had theorems involving `[Coalgebra R A]` outside of the namespace, would I want to have 
```
def  (R : Type u) {A : Type v} [CommRing R] [Ring A] [Module R A] [C : Coalgebra R A] := C.
```
just before them? (I did try ` (R := R)` but I couldn't get it working.)
I don'f fully understand what you mean, but if you have a version with fewer `C.`s, feel free to push it.

Ah, now I see: this is great, but I think the comment above will bite you eventually. In your case, Lean can work out `R` because it's an argument to `TensorProduct.assoc`. In general though, Lean might force you to write extra type annotations.

I think it's reasonable to leave it as is for now; but I predict you will end up running into this problem again in a future PR, and at that point we should revisit it.

Following the [naming guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html), we usually name things quite literally whenever we can.
```suggestion
theorem Finsupp._single_one (R : Type u) (S : Type v) [CommRing R] (s : S) :
```
I also recommend putting these in a `section` (or better yet, `namespace Finsupp`), and hoisting `R` and `S`  to a `variable` line at the start of the section.
Can you add a lemma about ` (Finsupp.single s r)`? (It's equal to `r`, right?)

Theorem names shouldn't mention the names of their variables, because the caller doesn't care about those:
```suggestion
theorem _single (s : S) (r : R) : (instCoalgebra R S). (Finsupp.single s r) = r := by
```

I think this is true more generally as
```suggestion
theorem _single (s : S) (r : R) : (instCoalgebra R S). (Finsupp.single s r) =
    Finsupp.single s r [R] Finsupp.single s 1 := by
```
though the proof might be harder
I think I've got this proven now

You shouldn't have to write `(instCoalgebra R S).` here; typeclass search finds the instance automatically (which is the whole point of `instance`!):
```suggestion
theorem _single (s : S) (r : R) :  (Finsupp.single s r) = r := by
```
Same above for ``
When I remove the `(instCoalgebra R S).` from this, I get the error `function expected at , term has type ?m.135475`, and same for ``. I'm not entirely sure why...
Oh, I guess it's because I'm not in the `Coalgebra` namespace anymore? `Coalgebra.` seems to work, but it's not much of an improvement
You can do `open Coalgebra` just before `namespace Finsupp`.

```suggestion

suppress_compilation

```
will fix the error below.
Ah ok thanks. Why was I getting that error, out of interest?

We disabled compilation (i.e., making actual real programs that run) for tensor products because it took too long, and we were never using the output anyway. The error is telling you "this function was never compiled".
Don't forget to add lemmas for these too!
These both look like good `@[simp]` lemmas to me

A good name for this would be
```suggestion
instance (R : Type u) [CommRing R] CommRing.toCoalgebra : Coalgebra R R where
```
(which matches `CommSemiring.toAlgebra`)

I was originally trying to steer you towards:
```lean
instance instCoalgebra [Coalgebra R A] : Coalgebra R (S  A) where
   := Finsupp.lsum R fun s => TensorProduct.map (Finsupp.lsingle s) (Finsupp.lsingle s)  
   := Finsupp.lsum R fun s => 
```
but I'm no longer sure if this is true, and if it is, proving it seems really awful!
I'm also not sure if this is true. I tried to think about it geometrically but just ended up confused. Interesting question!
I'm now reasonably confident this is true, and that we're just missing lots of lemmas that you'd need to prove it (so it's still not in scope for this PR).
Done in #8868
nit: I'd put this one before the `Finsupp` instance, it's more basic

Ideally we'd have a longer docstring; a good start would be
```suggestion
/-!
# Coalgebras

In this file we define `Coalgebra`, and provide instances for:

* Commutative rings: `CommRing.toCoalgebra`
* Finitely supported functions: `Finsupp.instCoalgebra`

## References

* Some ncatlab / wikipedia / bourbaki / ... reference of your choosing
-/
```
I think @adamtopaz can probably suggest something a little more in depth

I agree that a better module docstring would be more desirable -- this is the first thing people see in the docs when they navigate to the coalgebra page so it should reflect the contents of the file.

@adamtopaz, what do you think of using
```suggestion
  _id : TensorProduct.map  .id   = TensorProduct.mk R _ _ 1
```
instead? I found this much easier to use when proving the `Prod` instance:

<details>

```lean
namespace Prod
variable (R : Type u) (A : Type v) (B : Type*)
variable [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup A] [AddCommGroup B] [Module R A] [Module R B]

instance instCoalgebra [Coalgebra R A] [Coalgebra R B] : Coalgebra R (A  B) where
   := .coprod (TensorProduct.map (.inl _ _ _) (.inl _ _ _)  ) (TensorProduct.map (.inr _ _ _) (.inr _ _ _)  )
   := .coprod  
  id_ := by
    ext x : 2 <;> dsimp
     simp only [map_zero, add_zero]
      simp_rw [LinearMap.comp_apply, LinearMap.comp_assoc, TensorProduct.map_comp, LinearMap.id_comp,
        LinearMap.coprod_inl, LinearMap.comp_apply]
      suffices TensorProduct.map (LinearMap.inl R A B  .id) (.id  ) ( x) = (x, 0) [R] 1 by
        exact this
      rw [TensorProduct.map_comp, LinearMap.comp_apply, map_id__, TensorProduct.map_tmul]
      rfl
     simp only [map_zero, zero_add]
      simp_rw [LinearMap.comp_apply, LinearMap.comp_assoc, TensorProduct.map_comp, LinearMap.id_comp,
        LinearMap.coprod_inr, LinearMap.comp_apply]
      suffices TensorProduct.map (LinearMap.inr R A B  .id) (.id  ) ( x) = (0, x) [R] 1 by
        exact this
      rw [TensorProduct.map_comp, LinearMap.comp_apply, map_id__, TensorProduct.map_tmul]
      rfl
  _id := by
    sorry
  coassoc := by
    sorry

end Prod
```

</details>
(the difference is a single application of `(TensorProduct.lid R A).eq_symm_apply`)
Are you also proposing `  id_ : TensorProduct.map .id    = fun a  TensorProduct.mk R A R a 1` ? Because this looks a bit more clunky.
No, that would be `id_ : TensorProduct.map .id    = (TensorProduct.mk R A R).flip 1`; for `ext`, it's very important that it's an equality of maps, not just functions.
I agree with Eric here, I think there is a slight advantage to what he proposes.
If `(TensorProduct.mk R A R).flip` looks ugly, `(TensorProduct.rid R A).symm` would also be fine; but I don't think that's really an improvement.
See https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8621#discussion_r1414134327 for the updated version of this suggestion.

I extracted the `Prod` instance above to
* #8822

A minor thing: normally we reserve `S` for rings or semirings. For arbitrary index types, we tend to prefer `` (and `i : ` instead of `s : S` below):
```suggestion
variable ( : Type v)
```

We do not usually name structure field with symbols:
```suggestion
  comul : A [R] A [R] A
```
We can make the notation `` available by other means but I suggest leaving that to a follow-up PR.
Note that changing the field names will mean you should also change various lemma names below to contain `comul` and `counit` rather than `` and ``

As above, I suggest:
```suggestion
  counit : A [R] R
```

We usually prefer not to break a line inside a term
```suggestion
theorem coassoc_apply (a : A) :
    TensorProduct.assoc R A A A (TensorProduct.map  .id ( a)) = TensorProduct.map .id  ( a) :=
  LinearMap.congr_fun coassoc a
```
I took the liberty of pushing a commit that rewrites these to `.lTensor` and `.rTensor`, which is defeq but much shorter to write.
Thank you!

We indent lemma statements four spaces but proofs only two.
```suggestion
  LinearMap.congr_fun _id a
```

```suggestion
  LinearMap.congr_fun id_ a
```

You can pass multiple names to `unfold` as below.

More importantly, we only use `simp` to finish a proof (to reduce brittleness of proofs to changing `simp` labels). If you want to use `simp` in a non-finishing way then you can use `simp only [...explicit list of lemmas...]` (which `simp?` will generate for you) however in this case, it's easier just to pass the require lemma to your `rw`:
```suggestion
  unfold  instCoalgebra
  rw [total_single, TensorProduct.smul_tmul', smul_single_one i r]
```

```suggestion
  unfold  instCoalgebra; simp
```

Optional nitpick:
```suggestion
  coassoc := by ext; simp
```
(likewise the two fields below)

Unless you're doing fancy stuff where it's important  (e.g., large categories, logic) there's almost never any need to manually control universes. Lean is smart enough to do the right thing if you just write `R : Type*` instead of `R : Type u`.
You can even write thing like `R A : Type*` and Lean will allow `R` and `A` to live in different universes.
```suggestion
```
One small advantage of manual control is that the autogenerated `u_1` and `u_2` are less nice names than `u` and `v`.
@al-ramsey - just checking you saw this. I think both spellings are fine, but you should certainly be aware of `Type*`.

```suggestion
class Coalgebra (R A : Type*) [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup A] [Module R A] where
```

At least for now I think the section `CommRingAddCommGroup` is overkill, I suggest just:
```suggestion
variable {R A : Type*} [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup A] [Module R A] [Coalgebra R A]
```
Or even `[CommSemiring R] [AddCommMonoid A]`...
I pushed a change with that generalization
Thank you!

Note that https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8621#discussion_r1408558962 still applies here, as
```suggestion
  /-- The counit satisfies the left counitality law -/
  counit_id : counit.rTensor A  comul = TensorProduct.mk R _ _ 1
  /-- The counit satisfies the right counitality law -/
  id_counit : counit.lTensor A  comul = (TensorProduct.mk R _ _).flip 1
```

At this point it would probably make sense to rename the fields to` rTensor_counit_comp_comul` and `lTensor_counit_comp_comul`
When I change these, should I change the statements of the lemmas that apply them, or keep the same statements and change the proofs?

You should probably do both: add new lemmas with the new statements (which probably work with effectively the same old proofs), but also keep the old ones, with new proofs. The old statements should follow trivially from the new ones

It would be good to also prove
```lean
    (TensorProduct.assoc R A A A).symm (comul.lTensor A (comul a)) = comul.rTensor A (comul a) :=
```
I've pushed a proof of this, but it's pretty cluttered so I'm trying to find a better way to write it
There should be a trivial proof using `(TensorProduct.assoc R A A A).symm_apply_eq`
Ah, that makes things easier...

The RHS simplifies further here; can you write the simplified form?

One way you can find out is to start the proof with `dsimp`, then replace the RHS with the version after `dsimp`.

Same for the lemma below.
Can you also add the theorem that `(TensorProduct.assoc R A A A).symm  comul.lTensor A  comul = comul.rTensor A  comul`? It should follow from the lemma you just proved.

The naming convention suggests that the following might be a good name for this
```suggestion
theorem lTensor_counit_comul (a : A) : counit.lTensor A (comul a) = (TensorProduct.mk R _ _).flip 1 a :=
```
and similarly for the one above, with `rTensor`
These look good now, thanks!

```suggestion
theorem comul_single (i : ) (r : R) :
    comul (Finsupp.single i r) = (Finsupp.single i r) [R] (Finsupp.single i 1) := by
```

nodes.body: This looks like a great start; I'm glad to see this migrate from zulip to a PR!
A nice second example might be https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3694952/1896; I think that would make clear why I suggest the applied lemmas above.
Another good instance to add would be `Coalgebra R R`, which I think is true with the obvious maps.

In case you missed it; I think it would be a good idea to include this in this PR too.

> A nice second example might be https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3694952/1896; I think that would make clear why I suggest the applied lemmas above.

I agree but right now we don't need this so it could wait for another PR.

Thank you for this PR, it's great that coalgebras (and I hope Hopf algebras!) are finally arriving.

I have left some suggestions (mostly nitpicks, but I think worth following).

Note that first PRs are always the hardest, especially if they contain new definitions: you should definitely expect future PRs to be much more fun :-)

I'll look again as soon as you've addressed the open suggestions but please feel free to ping me here or on Zulip if you have questions.
LGTM, thanks for the final iteration!

Thanks!
